content:
Let’s break down the clues:

1. The façade is entirely clad in blue-and-white azulejo tiles depicting scenes from the founding of the Carmelite Order.
2. The ornate Rococo window frames, the stone statues atop the roofline, and the “narrow house” that separates two joined churches all match descriptions of Igreja do Carmo in Porto. ([portugalvisitor.com](https://www.portugalvisitor.com/porto-churches/carmo-carmelitas?utm_source=openai))
3. This church sits at the corner of Praça de Carlos Alberto and Rua do Carmo, in Porto’s historic Vitória parish (part of the Baixa/downtown district). ([pt.wikipedia.org](https://pt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Igreja_do_Carmo_%28Porto%29?utm_source=openai))
All evidence points to the famous tile-covered Carmelite church on Rua do Carmo in central Porto.
**Location Conclusion** Rua do Carmo, Vitória (Baixa) neighborhood, Porto, Portugal, Europe
